text: Theodora Velma Fonteneau Rutherford (January 28, 1904 - August 15, 1993) was an African-American accountant, clubwoman, and college instructor. In 1960 she became the first black CPA qualified in West Virginia. ==Early life== Theodora Velma Fonteneau was born in Jeanerette, Louisiana and raised in Houston, Texas. Her mother was a teacher, and her father owned a restaurant. In 1919 she was "Goddess of Liberty" in an Emancipation Day celebration parade in Houston."Negroes of Houston Pay Honors to Emancipation" The Houston Post (June 20, 1919): 11. via Newspapers.com ==Education== She attended Howard University, graduating summa cum laude in 1923, at the top of her class i the School of Commerce and Finance. The following year,"Theodora V. Fonteneau" The Crisis (July 1924): 124. she was the first black student to earn a master's degree in accounting at Columbia University.Theresa A. Hammond, A White-Collar Profession: African American Certified Public Accountants since 1921 (University of North Carolina Press 2003): 12-16. Her thesis title was "An accounting system for a small school or college".Essays for the Master's Degree 1924 (Columbia University Libraries 1924): 18. Fonteneau was unable to qualify as a Certified Public Accountant (CPA) after school, because she could not meet New York's experience requirement; no firm would hire a black woman accountant, even with Fonteneau's academic credentials. When there was a rule change in 1959, she became the first black CPA in West Virginia."Theresa A. Hammond, "Counting on Change: The History of African American CPAs" The Crisis (May/June 2002): 42. and the first black woman member of the West Virginia Society of Public Accountants.Wilma Higginbotham, "CPA Third Title Earned by Theodora Rutherford" Charleston Daily Mail (November 23, 1974): 4. via Newspapers.comLula Jones Garrett, "Mrs. Rutherford a C. P. A." Baltimore Afro American (February 16, 1960): 39. via NewspaperArchive.com ==Career== Fonteneau worked addressing envelopes in New York City while she was a graduate student. She moved to West Virginia in 1925, and built the business program at West Virginia Collegiate Institute (now West Virginia State University). Because her husband also worked for the school, she was forced by nepotism rules to leave her job during their marriage, from 1933 to 1957. She returned to teaching in widowhood. She retired from college teaching in 1973."Reception will Honor Retiring Faculty, Staff" Raleigh Register (May 10, 1973): 10. via NewspaperArchive.com Rutherford helped establish the West Virginia Collegiate Credit Union, was the credit union's first treasurer, and later served on the board of directors of the West Virginia Credit Union League."History" West Virginia Credit Union League."Credit Union Officers" The Weirton Daily Times (April 20, 1965): 9. via Newspapers.com She was president of the West Virginia Consumer Association and served on the boards of the Community Banking and Savings Company."Dunbar Group Seeks State Bank Charter" Charleston Gazette (June 27, 1972): 13. via Newspapers.com She taught community classes in tax preparation."3-Week Income Tax Workshop Set Soon" Bluefield Daily Telegraph (June 4, 1961): 25. via NewspaperArchive.com In 1963, she won a Ford Foundation fellowship, to pursue doctoral studies at Indiana University."Wins Fellowship" Morgantown Dominion News (May 15, 1963): 10. via NewspaperArchive.com After she retired, she ran an accounting firm, specializing in taxes. "Most older people have encouraged young black women to go into teaching, but I certainly would encourage them to go into accounting if they are capable," she told an interviewer in 1977.Ann Griffith, "State's First, Only Black Woman CPA Has Own Firm, Specializes in Taxes" Charleston Daily Mail (July 27, 1977): 21. via NewspaperArchive.com Rutherford was active in the Alpha Kappa Alpha (ΑΚΑ) sorority."Alpha Kappa Alphas Hold Fine Session Here" The Pittsburgh Courier (May 4, 1935): 8. via Newspapers.comWilliam H. Peeler, "Charming Sorors Enjoy Our City" The Pittsburgh Courier (May 4, 1935): 5. via Newspapers.com She was a charter member and first president of the ΑΚΑ graduate chapter at Charleston, West Virginia when it was founded in 1929."The History of Alpha Omicron Omega" Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Incorporated. She was also active in the League of Women Voters"Women Voters Plan First Fall Meetings" The Charleston Daily Mail (September 16, 1967): 6. via Newspapers.com and the Girl Scouts, and ran a summer camp for girls on the Coal River in the 1930s."A. K. A.'s Entertain School Principal" The Pittsburgh Courier (August 8, 1936): 8. via Newspapers.com In 1983, Rutherford was honored by Howard University for her lifetime of achievement, with fellow alumni Debbie Allen, Wayman Smith III, James E. Bowman, Gloria Twine Chisum, and Robert E. L. Perkins."Bennett is Speaker for HU Convocation" Washington Informer (March 2, 1983): 1. via ProQuest"Howard to Honor 6" Washington Informer (February 9, 1983): 2. via ProQuest ==Personal life== Theodora Fonteneau married Charles Robert Rutherford, who also worked at West Virginia State University. She was widowed when Charles died by suicide in 1956."College Man Shoots Self" Charleston Daily Mail (January 7, 1956): 3. via NewspaperArchive.com Her only child, Rosalie (1932-1976),"Mrs. Rosalie Morgan" Sunday Gazette-Mail (June 20, 1976): 47. via Newspapers.com was disabled in an accident as a young woman; Theodora Rutherford raised her granddaughter, Elvira Morgan (1958-1976)."Elvira Theresa Morgan" The Charleston Daily Mail (February 9, 1976): 8. via Newspapers.com ==Legacy== The Black Business Students Association at Columbia University awards a Theodora Fonteneau Rutherford Scholarship, named for Rutherford as the business school's first black graduate."Auction Raises Scholarship Funds — and Honors School‘s First African-American MBA" Columbia Business School (March 1, 2007). ==References== Category:American accountants Category:Howard University alumni Category:Columbia Business School alumni Category:West Virginia State University faculty Category:People from Jeanerette, Louisiana Category:1904 births Category:Year of death missing Category:1993 deaths
